bib_record.title: Production of chromium-48 for applications in life sciences

free_txt: Compact cyclotron 'CV28'.
And chemical processing.
/By authors/ Beam currents were determined by two
methods:
1) using a Faraday cup and comparison of activities:
in this method a thin foil of the material for which
excitation function were to be measured was placed in
front of the thick stack. Additionally another foil of
the same material and thickness as that in front of
the stack was irradiated independently (without stack)
and the total charge was collected in a Faraday cup.
The average beam current incident on the stack was
then obtained from a comparison of the various
activities produced in the independently irradiated
foil with those in the front foil of the stack after
applying the relevant corrections such as for foil
thickness, irradiation times, etc.
2) via a monitor reaction: for the determination of
beam currents via monitor reactions, several aluminium
foils were placed at different positions in each stack.
From the 24Na activity produced in each monitor foil
the beam current was calculated.
80 cm 3 Ge(Li) detector in conjunction
with a 4K analyzer
Compact cyclotron 'CV28'.
This is
stopping power tables.
Details on
the estimation of individual errors have been described
By authors. Since 51-V occurs in natural vanadium
with an abundance of 99.75%, the 51-Cr should almost
exclusively be formed in interactions of deuteron with
The total errors in the cross section data
were obtained by summing up in quadrature all the
individual errors such as:
* statistical errors,
* errors in the analysis of the gamma-ray peaks,
* errors in beam current measurements,
* uncertainty in the efficiency of the detector.
This is typical cross section uncertainty
in general, the error in the rising part of excitation
curves amounted to 12% and at the peaks to 6-8%.
Two stacks were irradiated. The first one consisted of
39 foils and the second one of 19 foils.
The thickness of the vanadium foils varied between
25 and 115 um. The purity of vanadium was better
than 99.8%.
Fig.1 from Int.J.Appl.Rad.Isot.,31(1980)223
Monitor reaction

vanadium with an abundance of 99.75%,
the 49-Cr should almost exclusively be
formed in interactions of deuterons with 51-V.

Titanium of natural isotopic composition,
purity is better than 99.6%.
The titanium foils used were 10, 35 and 125 um thick
and arranged such that the energy interval between
two successive points on the excitation curve
varied between 1.8 And 5 MeV. The thickness of each
foil was determined independently.

Compiler could not exclude the production
of 47-Sc via 47-Ca and 47-K.
*By author*. The data have been measured using
both the high-energy machine (thick stack)
and the low-energy machine (relatively thin stack).
The discrepancies have been observed for energy
overlap region in the case of different stacks.
For thick stack secondary neutrons contribute
to the formation of scandium via (n,p) and (n,n'p)
reactions.
The total errors in the cross section data
were obtained by summing up in quadrature all the
individual errors such as:
* statistical errors,
* errors in the analysis of the gamma-ray peaks,
* errors in beam current measurements,
* uncertainty in the efficiency of the detector.
This is typical cross section uncertainty
in general, the error in the rising part of excitation
curves amounted to 12% and at the peaks to 6-8%.

A stack consisting of 54 aluminium foils (purity is
better than 99.99%) of thicknesses varying between
100 and 500 um was irradiated with deuterons.
